Fancy Qubits.¶

The basic qubit runs at the speed of C++ when numpy uses MKL. To maintain that speed, operations that harm performance are separated into FancyQubits. Currently, there are two main features in FancyQubits.

  1. Euler angle.
  2. Qubit Visualization.

SfqFancyQubit¶

class sfqQubit.SfqFancyQubit(d_theta=0.015707963267948967, w_clock=31415926535.89793, w_qubit=(31415926535.89793, 61575216010.35995), theta=1.5707963267948966)[source]¶

Qubit enhanced with additional features, which are separated from the basic qubits to preserve their speed.

__init__(d_theta=0.015707963267948967, w_clock=31415926535.89793, w_qubit=(31415926535.89793, 61575216010.35995), theta=1.5707963267948966)[source]¶

This constructor is not intended to be used. Do not call this.

alpha_list¶

List of \(\alpha\) Euler angle

beta_list¶

List of \(\beta\) Euler angle

gamma_list¶

List of \(\gamma\) Euler angle

kets¶

The 6 cardinal rotated states.

Returns:The 6 cardinal rotated states.
measure_fidelity()¶

Measure the fidelity. Implement in subclasses.

precess()[source]¶

Precess the qubit for one clock period.

pulse_and_precess()¶

Rotate the qubit for d_theta around y-axis, then precess for one clock period.

pulse_pattern(pattern)¶

Evolve the qubit according to a sequence of 0 (precession) and 1 (sfq pulse_and_precess).

Parameters:pattern – The pulse sequence.
resonance()¶

Apply a resonance pulse sequence to the qubit.

set_plot_kets(plot_kets=None)[source]¶

Choose which kets to plot. Plotting too many kets may lead to performance issues.

Parameters:plot_kets – A list of kets to plot. The followings are supported.
  • ‘G’: Ground (+z)
  • ‘E’: Excited (-z)
  • ‘P’: (+x)
  • ‘P_I’: (+y)
  • ‘M’: (-x)
  • ‘M_I’: (-y)

For example, to plot the ground state and the excited state, pass in [‘G’, ‘E’].

class sfqQubit.Sfq2LevelFancyQubit(axes, d_theta=0.015707963267948967, w_clock=31415926535.89793, w_qubit=(31415926535.89793, 61575216010.35995), theta=1.5707963267948966)[source]¶

Call the constructor of Sfq2LevelQubit. Then prepare the visualization on the provided axes.

Parameters:axes – Axes on which visualization will be made.
kets¶

The 6 cardinal rotated states.

Returns:The 6 cardinal rotated states.
measure_fidelity(method='states')¶

Measure the fidelity of the rotation applied to the qubit.

Parameters:method – Currently only states is implemented. TODO Implement ‘gates’.
Returns:The fidelity.

Parameters:pattern – The pulse sequence.

set_plot_kets(plot_kets=None)¶

Choose which kets to plot. Plotting too many kets may lead to performance issues.

Parameters:plot_kets – A list of kets to plot. The followings are supported.
  • ‘G’: Ground (+z)
  • ‘E’: Excited (-z)
  • ‘P’: (+x)
  • ‘P_I’: (+y)
  • ‘M’: (-x)
  • ‘M_I’: (-y)

For example, to plot the ground state and the excited state, pass in [‘G’, ‘E’].

kets¶

The 6 cardinal rotated states.

Returns:The 6 cardinal rotated states.
measure_fidelity(method='states', ignore_leakage=False)¶

Measure the fidelity of the rotation applied to the qubit.

Parameters:
  • method – Either ‘states’ or ‘gates’.
  • ignore_leakage – Do not account for the leakage level when computing fidelity.
Returns:

The fidelity.
